Feedback
To report a bug or make a suggestion regarding the &app; application or this manual, follow the directions in the GNOME Feedback Page.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; is a graphical tool that lets you schedule tasks with ease, to be run unattended at a specified time or periodically. These tasks, also known as jobs, can be either a command with its corresponding parameters or a script file with multiple instructions.
You can use &app; to program repetitive tasks in your daily work that can be automated or to run a heavy task at night while you are sleeping, for example, backing-up your documents.

sect2.title: How does &app; work?
sect2.para: &app; uses cron and at to program job executions. These are two system services commonly used by Linux-like systems. &app; provides a single graphical interface to configure both of them and present jobs in a way easy to understand for everyone.

sect2.title: About cron and at
sect2.para:
If you were to configure cron manually to execute a command, for example every Tuesday, you would have to use the command crontab in this way:
$ crontab -e * * * * 2 <command> #comments

tip.para: See man cron and man crontab for more information about cron

sect2.para:
If you were to configure at manually to execute a command, for example tomorrow at this time, you would have to use the commandat in this way:
$ at tomorrow at> ls --parameters at> Ctrl + D

tip.para: See man at for more information about at

sect2.title: When You Start &app;
sect2.para: When you start &app;, the main window is displayed:

textobject.phrase: Shows &app; main window. Contains title bar, menu bar, tool bar, and task list.

sect2.para: The &app; main window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: The menus on the menu bar gives you access to every option in the application.
The tool bar gives you direct access to the most common options from the menubar.

The Task list shows information about current scheduled tasks and pending jobs. For every task, the following information is detailed:
Icon:
Image associated to the task.
Type:
Describes the type of the task: "Recurrent" or "Once".
Title:
Shows the name of the task.
Date and Time Settings:
Shows when the task is going to be executed.
Preview:
Shows the command that is going to be executed.

tip.para: You can read a brief description of some of the objects on the &app; interface, by pointing them with the mouse and waiting for a few seconds.

sect1.title: Adding a New Scheduled Task
sect1.para:
You can add a new scheduled task by pressing the Add button in the main window tool bar or by selecting
Task New in the menu bar.
The following dialog window will appear letting you to choose the type of task you want to schedule:

textobject.phrase: Shows &app; task type selection dialog window.

listitem.para: by selecting the first option you will be able to schedule a task that will be executed periodically.
by selecting the second option you will be able to schedule a task that will only be executed once.

sect1.title: Modifying a Scheduled Task
sect1.para:
You can modify a scheduled task by selecting it from the Task list with one click and by pressing the Properties button in the main window tool bar or, alternatively, by selecting
Task Properties on the menu bar. Then, the Edit a Scheduled Task window will be opened showing the task properties.
Now, you will be able to modify any field you want. When you have finished you can press OK button to save the changes or Cancel button to omit them.

tip.para: You can edit a task faster by simply double-clicking on it.

sect1.title: Deleting a Scheduled Task
sect1.para:
You can delete a scheduled task by selecting it from the Task list with one click and by pressing the Delete button in the main window tool bar or by selecting
Task Delete . Next, you will be asked for confirmation. By pressing the OK button, the scheduled task will be removed from the Task list.

sect1.title: Using Templates
sect1.para: &app; lets you save tasks as templates in order to reuse it later. So, you will be able to create new scheduled tasks faster.
To manage templates use the Template drop-down list on the properties window when you are adding or editing a tasks.

listitem.para: To create a new template, first write a name for it in the Template drop-down list. Next, fill in the fields you want to save in the template. And, finally, press Save button.
To modify a template, first choose it from the drop-down list. Next, change the fields you want to modify. And, finally, press Save button.
To delete a template choose it from the drop-down list and then press the Delete button.
To use a previously saved template drop-down the list and select it. The fields will be automatically filled in with the template options.

sect1.para: If you do not want to use templates select the default option Don't use a preset from the drop-down list.

tip.para: You can have common tasks saved as templates. So, you will not have to write the same stuff again and again!

sect1.title: Using the Advanced View
sect1.para: &app; lets you add, edit and view scheduled task in a crontab-like style.

You can activate the advanced view by choosing
View Advanced on the main window menu bar. You will notice that the information shown in the Task list change into a crontab-like style. Now, if you try to add a new recurrent task the Advanced tab will be shown by default in the Create a New Scheduled Task window.

textobject.phrase: Shows the Advanced tab in the "Create a New Scheduled Task" window

sect1.para: Those who feel comfortable using crontab will find this option very interesting.

sect1.title: Using &app; as root
sect1.para: When you use &app; as superuser, you can view, edit and add other users scheduled tasks.

You can change the user by pressing the Change User button in the main window tool bar or, alternatively, by selecting
Task Change User from the menu bar. Then, a dialog window will be shown. Choose the desired user from the drop-down list and press OK button. Now the main window will show the scheduled tasks of the selected user.
